raw_text:
Blair to face trust issue head on
 
 Tony Blair says he will be facing the issue of trust and his own integrity head on during the election campaign.
 
 During a question and answer session with first-time voters on Five News, Mr Blair said he had no option but to "confront it" by talking to people. He also dismissed claims government plans to get 50% of young people into university would devalue degrees. He was not "forcing" anyone to go to university, but places should be there for those who wanted them, he said. In answer to a question from 22-year-old Liverpool student David Dunne about concerns over the prime minister's personal integrity, Mr Blair said talking was the only answer. "You've just got to confront it and say to people let's have a discussion on the things that worry you, the things that make you say 'I can't trust you' or 'I am against you on this.'" The "worst thing in politics" was that the electorate only got "little snatches of policy" from things like Prime Minister's Questions and the news headlines. This was why he wanted to "get out of the 30 seconds on the news," he added.
 
 By talking through policies at least people understood the reason for them, even if they did not agree with them, he said. Mr Blair also faced questions about British policy on Iran and its alleged nuclear weapons programme. He insisted there was no plan for an invasion of the country saying: "Sometimes people say because of what has happened in Iraq this is the next place." Instead there was a real chance of a "peaceful resolution" to the problem, he said.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair will face trust issues during his election campaign and will confront them head-on by talking to people directly.
He rejects claims that government plans to get 50% of young people into university would devalue degrees.
Instead, Blair says places should be available for those who want them.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair will address trust and integrity issues directly during his election campaign, stating that talking to people is the only way to confront these concerns.
He also plans to discuss policies in more detail, hoping to educate people about their reasons, even if they disagree with them.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair plans to openly discuss trust issues and his own integrity during the election campaign.
He will engage in conversations with voters about their concerns regarding government policies and the prime minister's personal integrity.
He believes talking through policies will increase understanding even if people disagree with them.
Blair also addressed concerns about British policy on Iran, asserting there is no plan for an invasion but a possibility of peaceful resolution.

qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair addresses trust issue during election campaign, stating that discussing policy can help voters understand its reasons even if they disagree with it and opposing plans for an invasion of Iran in response to allegations of nuclear weapons development.
qwen2.5:3b: Blair plans to openly address trust issues and his integrity during the election campaign.
He denies forcing anyone into university and insists that education places should be available for those who want them.
Blair suggested engaging in discussions with voters about their concerns regarding his personal credibility.

He emphasized the importance of explaining policies fully rather than relying on short news snippets, believing this would lead to a better understanding of government actions despite differing opinions.
Blair also addressed British policy towards Iran, stating there is no plan for an invasion and maintaining hope for a peaceful resolution.

He dismissed plans to get 50% of young people into university as devaluing degrees but placed options for those who wanted them.

He also answered questions about Iran's nuclear weapons program, dismissing claims of an invasion and instead highlighted Iraq's situation as a real possibility.

He dismisses claims that plans to get 50% of young people into universities would degrade degrees as merely a means to "force" people to take them.

tinydolphin:1.1b: The text states that Tony Blair will face a trust issue during his election campaign due to his reluctance to confront it head-on, by having a question and answer session with young people on Five News.

In response to a question from a Liverpool student about the personal integrity of the Prime Minister, Mr. Blair dismissed concerns over trust by answering in favor of talking, emphasizing the importance of having a discussion on matters of concern.

Speaking to first-time voters, he emphasized the importance of open dialogue to address doubts.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair acknowledges trust and personal integrity as key election issues, planning to address them directly with voters during his campaign.

In a Q&A on Five News, he dismissed concerns about devaluing degrees due to increased university enrollment targets, emphasizing that no one is forced into higher education, but opportunities should be available for those who desire it.
Blair believes the "worst thing in politics" is limited policy exposure through brief news segments or Prime Minister's Questions.
To combat this, he aims to engage voters on policies' reasons, regardless of their agreement.

He also addressed British Iran policy, clarifying there are no plans for an invasion and instead advocating for a peaceful resolution to the nuclear weapons issue, citing past mistakes from the Iraq conflict.
